title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: Instrumental variable (IV) methods widely used economics, epidemiology, social sciences estimate causal effects presence unobserved confounding. valid IV approach requires , conditionally observed covariates, instrument confounded outcome, influences outcome affecting uptake treatment. first assumption usually called “exogeneity,” “ignorability,” “unconfoundedness” instrument, whereas second usually called “exclusion restriction.” However, assumptions often violated practice due presence omitted confounders instrument; , even instrument randomized, omitted side-effects instrument influencing outcome via paths treatment. assumptions fail, bias IV estimate may fact worse original confounding bias naive regression estimate. Researchers therefore often advised perform sensitivity analyses assess degree violation IV assumptions required alter conclusions IV study. package iv.sensemakr aims help task, implementing suite sensitivity analysis tools IV estimates developed Cinelli Hazlett (2025), builds omitted variable bias (OVB) framework Cinelli Hazlett (2020). goal iv.sensemakr make easier understand violations unconfoundedness instrument exclusion restriction affect original findings study.

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: Since sensitivity analysis requires contextual knowledge properly interpreted, illustrate basic functionality package real example. reproduce results found Section 5 Cinelli Hazlett (2025). Card (1993) used proximity college instrumental variable estimate causal effect education earnings. revisit study quantify robust initial findings violations IV assumptions.

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: card dataset included package, consists sample n=3,010n = 3{,}010 individuals National Longitudinal Survey Young Men. key variables : lwage: log hourly wage 1976 (outcome). educ: years completed education (treatment). nearc4: indicator proximity four-year college (instrument). also various covariates, experience (exper), experience squared (expersq), race (black), whether individual lived standard metropolitan area (smsa), geographic region dummies. One can load dataset following command.
code: # load the package library(iv.sensemakr)  # load the dataset data("card")

what: OLS findings and the OVB problem
title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: regression log wages (YY) years education (DD), adjusting race, experience, regional factors (XX), Card found additional year schooling associated approximately 7.5% higher wages. can reproduce finding simple OLS regression. However, educational achievement randomly assigned. Individuals obtain education may higher wages reasons, family background, regional differences, higher levels unobserved characteristic ability motivation. Regression estimates , adjust partial list characteristics, may thus suffer omitted variable bias, likely overestimating true returns schooling. motivates use instrumental variables.
code: # OLS regression of log wages on education and covariates card.ols <- lm(lwage ~ educ + exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 +                   reg662 + reg663 + reg664 + reg665 + reg666 +                   reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                 data = card) coef(card.ols)["educ"] #>       educ  #> 0.07469326 confint(card.ols)["educ", ] #>      2.5 %     97.5 %  #> 0.06783385 0.08155266

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: IV methods offer alternative route estimating causal effect schooling earnings without data unobserved variables. key find new variable—instrument, denoted ZZ—changes incentives educational achievement, associated earnings effect education. Card proposed exploiting role geographic differences college accessibility instrumental variable. instrument nearc4 encodes whether individual grew near four-year college. Students grow far college may face higher educational costs, discouraging pursuing higher-level studies. importantly, Card argues whether one lives near college confounded earnings, cause earnings apart effect years education. Given two assumptions, one can use nearc4 IV effect educ lwage. estimates can obtained using iv_fit() function, takes input vectors outcome y, treatment d, instrument z, optional covariate matrix x. computes IV estimates using Anderson-Rubin (AR) approach (Anderson Rubin, 1949), numerically equivalent Two-Stage Least Squares (2SLS) point estimation, constructs confidence intervals via test inversion, procedure correct coverage regardless instrument strength. IV estimate suggests additional year schooling raises wages 13.2%, positive , perhaps surprisingly, much higher simple OLS estimate 7.5%. much can trust IV estimate? proximity college really valid instrument?
code: # prepare data y <- card$lwage  # outcome: log wage d <- card$educ   # treatment: years of education z <- card$nearc4 # instrument: proximity to college x <- model.matrix(~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 +                      reg662 + reg663 + reg664 + reg665 + reg666 +                      reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                    data = card)  # fit the IV model card.fit <- iv_fit(y, d, z, x) card.fit #>  #> Instrumental Variable Estimation #> (Anderson-Rubin Approach) #> ============================================= #> IV Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.132 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.025, 0.285] #> Note: H0 = 0, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ============================================= #> See summary for first stage and reduced form.

what: The IV estimate may suffer from omitted variable bias
title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: previous IV estimate relies assumption , conditional XX, proximity college earnings unconfounded, effect proximity earnings goes entirely education. often case, neither assumption easy defend. factors might confound relationship education earnings similarly confound relationship proximity college earnings (e.g., family wealth connections). Moreover, presence college nearby may associated high school quality, turn also affects earnings. Finally, geographic factors can make localities likely colleges nearby lead higher earnings—coarsely conditioned observed regional indicators, residual biases may remain. Therefore, instead adjusting XX , adjusted observed covariates XXand unobserved covariates WW, WW stands unobserved factors necessary make proximity college valid instrument effect education earnings. IV estimates model omitting WW compare estimates actually want, model includes WW?

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: main function package sensemakr(). takes iv_fit object input performs commonly required sensitivity analyses, can explored print, summary, plot methods. begin applying sensemakr card.fit object. arguments call : model: iv_fit object original IV regression. benchmark_covariates: names observed covariates used bound plausible strength omitted variables. use "black" (indicator race) "smsa" (indicator whether individual lived standard metropolitan area). kz, ky: arguments parameterize many times stronger omitted variables related instrument (kz) untreated potential outcome (ky) comparison observed benchmark covariates. example, setting kz=1 ky=1 means consider unobserved confounders side-effects strong "black" "smsa". q: fraction effect estimate explained away deemed problematic. Setting q = 1, , means reduction 100% current effect estimate—, true effect zero—problematic. default 1. alpha: significance level interest statistical inference. default 0.05. Using default arguments, one can simplify previous call :
code: # with all parameters shown explicitly card.sens <- sensemakr(model = card.fit,                        benchmark_covariates = c("black", "smsa"),                        kz = 1,               # benchmark multiplier for Z                        ky = 1,               # benchmark multiplier for Y                        q = 1,                # reduce estimate to zero                        alpha = 0.05)         # significance level card.sens <- sensemakr(card.fit, benchmark_covariates = c("black", "smsa"))

previous_headings: Estimating the returns to schooling > Sensitivity analysis
title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: print method sensemakr provides quick review original estimate along two summary sensitivity statistics suited routine reporting. robustness value (RV) describes minimum partial R2R^2 confounders side-effects need instrument untreated potential outcome order make adjusted confidence interval include zero. Card example, RV 0.67%, revealing confounders side-effects explaining 0.67% residual variation instrument potential outcome already sufficiently strong make IV estimate statistically insignificant. hand, confounders explain least 0.67% residual variation instrument potential outcome sufficiently strong . extreme robustness value (XRV) describes minimum strength association omitted variables need instrument alone order problematic. XRV 0.05% means , willing impose constraints partial R2R^2 omitted variables outcome, omitted variables need explain 0.05% residual variation instrument problematic. worst-case measure: considers scenario confounders may explain arbitrarily large share outcome’s residual variation, asks much instrument’s variation still need explain. useful quantities summarize need know order safely rule confounders side-effects deemed problematic. Interpreting values requires domain knowledge data-generating process. values 0.67% 0.05% enough confident original findings? One way assess plausibility omitted variables strength consider confounders side-effects strong observed covariates. given table named “Bounds Omitted Variable Bias,” shows strong omitted variables strong black smsa. can see, variables sufficiently strong overturn results original study. Since difficult imagine residual confounding strong stronger variables (e.g., parental income, finer-grained geographic location, etc), results already sufficient call question strength evidence provided study.
code: card.sens #>  #> Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables #> (Anderson-Rubin Approach) #> ============================================================= #> IV Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.132 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.025, 0.285] #>  #> Sensitivity Statistics: #>   Extreme Robustness Value: 0.000523 #>   Robustness Value: 0.00667 #>  #> Bounds on Omitted Variable Bias: #>  Bound Label  R2zw.x R2y0w.zx Lower CI Upper CI Crit. Thr. #>     1x black 0.00221   0.0750  -0.0212    0.402       2.59 #>      1x smsa 0.00639   0.0202  -0.0192    0.396       2.57 #>  #> Note: H0 = 0, q >= 1, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ============================================================= #> See summary for first stage and reduced form.

previous_headings: Estimating the returns to schooling > Sensitivity analysis
title: Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables using `iv.sensemakr`
text: previous sensitivity table provides good summary robust current estimate confounding. However, researchers may wish refine analysis visually exploring full range possible estimates omitted variables different strengths produce. , one can use plot method sensemakr.  left plot shows bounds lower limit confidence interval, whereas right plot shows bounds upper limit. cases, horizontal axis shows hypothetical partial R2R^2 omitted variables instrument, vertical axis shows hypothetical partial R2R^2 omitted variables untreated potential outcome. contour lines show lower upper limit confidence interval , adjusted omitted variables hypothetical strengths. point labeled “Observed” origin represents original IV estimate, assumes violation IV assumptions. move away origin—, hypothetical omitted variables become stronger—confidence interval widens. red dashed line marks critical threshold (zero), well boundary beyond confidence intervals become unbounded. labeled points show benchmark bounds observed covariates black smsa, indicating confounders comparable strength fall plot. Note scenario can also contemplated , simply picking different pairs R2R^2 values. seen previous analysis, confounding strong "smsa" "black" lead interval [-0.02, 0.40], includes implausibly high values (40%) also negative values (-2%) showing IV estimate fragile residual confounding magnitudes.
code: plot(card.sens, lim = 0.09)

title: Sensitivity Analysis Tools for Instrumental Variable Estimates
code: # loads package library(iv.sensemakr)  # loads dataset data("card")  # prepares data y <- card$lwage  # outcome d <- card$educ   # treatment z <- card$nearc4 # instrument x <- model.matrix( ~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 + reg662 +                      reg663 + reg664 + reg665+ reg666 + reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                    data = card) # covariates # fits IV model card.fit <- iv_fit(y,d,z,x)  # see results card.fit #>  #> Instrumental Variable Estimation #> (Anderson-Rubin Approach) #> ============================================= #> IV Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.132 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.025, 0.285] #> Note: H0 = 0, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ============================================= #> See summary for first stage and reduced form.  # runs sensitivity analysis card.sens <- sensemakr(card.fit, benchmark_covariates = c("black", "smsa"))  # see results card.sens #>  #> Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables #> (Anderson-Rubin Approach) #> ============================================================= #> IV Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.132 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.025, 0.285] #>  #> Sensitivity Statistics: #>   Extreme Robustness Value: 0.000523 #>   Robustness Value: 0.00667 #>  #> Bounds on Omitted Variable Bias: #>  Bound Label  R2zw.x R2y0w.zx Lower CI Upper CI Crit. Thr. #>     1x black 0.00221   0.0750  -0.0212    0.402       2.59 #>      1x smsa 0.00639   0.0202  -0.0192    0.396       2.57 #>  #> Note: H0 = 0, q >= 1, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ============================================================= #> See summary for first stage and reduced form.  # sensitivity contour plot plot(card.sens, lim = 0.09) # latex code for sensitivity table ovb_minimal_reporting(card.sens, outcome_label = "lwage", treatment_label = "educ") #> \begin{table}[!h] #> \centering #> \begin{tabular}{lrrrrrr} #> \multicolumn{7}{c}{Outcome: \textit{lwage}} \\ #> \hline \hline  #> Treatment: & Est. & Lower CI & Upper CI & t-value & $XRV_{q = 1, \alpha = 0.05}$ & $RV_{q = 1, \alpha = 0.05}$  \\  #> \hline  #> \textit{educ} & 0.132 & 0.025 & 0.285 & 2.327 & 0.1\% & 0.7\% \\  #> \hline  #> df = 2994 & & \multicolumn{5}{r}{ \small \textit{Bound (1x black)}: $R^2_{Z\sim W| {\bf X}}$ = 0.2\%, $R^2_{Y(0)\sim W| Z, {\bf X}}$ = 7.5\%} \\ #> \end{tabular} #> \end{table} # html code for sensitivity table ovb_minimal_reporting(card.sens, format = "pure_html",                       outcome_label = "lwage", treatment_label = "educ")

title: Extract estimates of an iv.sensemakr object — coef.iv.sensemakr
text: object object class iv_fit. parm estimate return. Options "iv" instrumental variable estimate, "fs" first-stage estimate "rf" reduced-form estimate. ... arguments passed methods.

title: Extract estimates of an iv.sensemakr object — coef.iv.sensemakr
text: data.frame sensitivity statistics requested parameters.

title: Extract estimates of an iv.sensemakr object — coef.iv.sensemakr
code: data("card") y <- card$lwage d <- card$educ z <- card$nearc4 x <- model.matrix( ~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 + reg662 +                      reg663 + reg664 + reg665+ reg666 + reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                    data = card) card.fit <- iv_fit(y, d, z, x) card.sens <- sensemakr(card.fit, benchmark_covariates = "black") coef(card.sens) #>     estimate        lwr       upr  t.value       xrv_qa       rv_qa q min alpha #> iv 0.1315038 0.02480484 0.2848236 2.327075 0.0005232443 0.006666407 1   1  0.05 #>     dof #> iv 2994 coef(card.sens, parm = "fs") #>     estimate       lwr       upr t.value      xrv_qa      rv_qa q min alpha #> fs 0.3198989 0.1476194 0.4921785 3.64085 0.003129076 0.03023129 1   1  0.05 #>     dof #> fs 2994

code: # S3 method for class 'iv_fit' coef(object, parm = "iv", ...)  # S3 method for class 'iv_fit' confint(object, parm = c("iv", "fs", "rf"), level, ...)

title: Extracts point estimates and confidence intervals of an iv_fit model. — coef.iv_fit
text: object object class iv_fit. parm estimate return. Options "iv" instrumental variable estimate, "fs" first-stage estimate "rf" reduced-form estimate. ... arguments passed methods. level coverage level (.e, 1-alpha). provided, uses level one provided iv_fit.

title: Extracts point estimates and confidence intervals of an iv_fit model. — coef.iv_fit
text: coef returns numeric vector estimates interest. confint returns numeric vector confidence interval interest.

title: Extracts point estimates and confidence intervals of an iv_fit model. — coef.iv_fit
code: # prepare data data("card") y <- card$lwage d <- card$educ z <- card$nearc4 x <- model.matrix( ~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 + reg662 +                      reg663 + reg664 + reg665+ reg666 + reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                    data = card)  # fit iv model card.fit <- iv_fit(y, d, z, x)  # extract coefficients coef(card.fit) #>        iv  #> 0.1315038  coef(card.fit, parm = "fs") #>        fs  #> 0.3198989  coef(card.fit, parm = "rf") #>         rf  #> 0.04206794   # extract confidence intervals confint(card.fit) #> IV conf. interval: #> [0.025, 0.285] #> level = 0.95 confint(card.fit, parm = "fs") #>        2.5 %    97.5 % #> fs 0.1476194 0.4921785 confint(card.fit, parm = "rf") #>          2.5 %     97.5 % #> rf 0.006622162 0.07751371

what: Instrumental Variable Estimation using the Anderson-Rubin approach — iv_fit
title: Instrumental Variable Estimation using the Anderson-Rubin approach — iv_fit
text: iv_fit computes instrumental variable estimates confidence intervals using Anderson-Rubin (AR) approach (Anderson Rubin, 1949).  approach numerically identical Fieller's theorem (Fieller, 1954). See Cinelli Hazlett (2025) discussion. AR point estimate numerically identical point estimate two-stage least squares (2SLS) given ratio reduced-form first-stage regression coefficient. Confidence intervals, however, constructed differently. 2SLS equivalent using delta-method obtain variance ratio estimator, proceeding assuming ratio asymptotically normal. approximation can fail instruments "weak." Anderson-Rubin approach instead uses test inversion procedure construct confidence intervals. procedure correct coverage regardless instrument strength, (inevitable) cost eventually obtaining unbounded confidence intervals.

title: Instrumental Variable Estimation using the Anderson-Rubin approach — iv_fit
code: iv_fit(y, d, z, x = NULL, h0 = 0, alpha = 0.05)

title: Instrumental Variable Estimation using the Anderson-Rubin approach — iv_fit
text: y numeric vector outcome. d numeric vector treatment. z numeric vector instrument. x (optional) numeric matrix observed covariates. h0 null hypothesis target parameter (IV estimate). alpha significance test hypothesis tests confidence intervals.

title: Instrumental Variable Estimation using the Anderson-Rubin approach — iv_fit
text: object class iv_fit, containing: data data.frame data used fitting models. models list lm models used obtaining IV estimates. includes first-stage (FS), reduced-form (RF), Anderson-Rubin (AR) regressions. estimates list summary information IV estimates, well summary information auxiliary estimates FS, RF, AR regression. pars list parameters call, null hypothesis h0 significance level alpha.

title: Instrumental Variable Estimation using the Anderson-Rubin approach — iv_fit
text: Anderson, T.W. Rubin, H. (1949), Estimation parameters single equation complete system stochastic equations, Annals Mathematical Statistics, 20, 46-63. Fieller, E. C. (1954). problems interval estimation. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Methodological), 16(2), 175-185. Cinelli, C. Hazlett, C. (2025), "Omitted Variable Bias Framework Sensitivity Analysis Instrumental Variables." Biometrika. doi:10.1093/biomet/asaf004

title: Instrumental Variable Estimation using the Anderson-Rubin approach — iv_fit
code: # prepare data data("card") y <- card$lwage d <- card$educ z <- card$nearc4 x <- model.matrix( ~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 + reg662 +                      reg663 + reg664 + reg665+ reg666 + reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                    data = card)  # fit iv model card.fit <- iv_fit(y, d, z, x) card.fit #>  #> Instrumental Variable Estimation #> (Anderson-Rubin Approach) #> ============================================= #> IV Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.132 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.025, 0.285] #> Note: H0 = 0, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ============================================= #> See summary for first stage and reduced form. #>  summary(card.fit) #>  #> Instrumental Variable Estimation #> (Anderson-Rubin Approach) #> ============================================= #> IV Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.132 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.025, 0.285] #> Note: H0 = 0, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> --------------------------------------------- #> FS Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.32 #>   Standard Error: 0.0879 #>   t-value: 3.64 #>   p-value: 0.000276 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.148, 0.492] #> Note: H0 = 0, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> --------------------------------------------- #> RF Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.0421 #>   Standard Error: 0.0181 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.007, 0.078] #> Note: H0 = 0, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ============================================= #>

what: Contour plots of omitted variable bias for IV — ovb_contour_plot
title: Contour plots of omitted variable bias for IV — ovb_contour_plot
text: Contour plots omitted variable bias sensitivity analysis instrumental variable estimates. main inputs iv_fit model, covariates used benchmarking strength omitted variables. parm = "iv" (default) contour plots IV estimate shown. horizontal axis plot shows hypothetical values partial R2 latent variables instrument. vertical axis shows hypothetical values partial R2 latent variables (pot.) outcome. contour levels represent adjusted lower limit (upper limit) Anderson-Rubin confidence interval IV estimate, t-value testing specific null hypothesis.  reference points bounds partial R2 latent variables k times "strong" observed covariate used benchmarking (see arguments kz ky). dotted red line show chosen critical threshold (instance, zero): latent variables strength (stronger) sufficient invalidate research conclusions. parm = "fs" parm = "rf", contour plots first-stage reduced-form regression shown. See, e.g, ovb_contour_plot.lm. See Cinelli Hazlett (2020, 2025) details.

title: Contour plots of omitted variable bias for IV — ovb_contour_plot
code: ovb_contour_plot(...)  # S3 method for class 'iv_fit' ovb_contour_plot(   model,   benchmark_covariates = NULL,   kz = 1,   ky = kz,   kd = kz,   sensitivity.of = c("lwr", "upr", "t-value"),   parm = "iv",   r2zw.x = NULL,   r2y0w.zx = r2zw.x,   bound_label = "manual bound",   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   ... )

title: Contour plots of omitted variable bias for IV — ovb_contour_plot
text: ... arguments graphical parameters. model model created function iv_fit. benchmark_covariates character vector names covariates used bound plausible strength latent variables. kz numeric vector. Parameterizes many times stronger latent variables related instrument comparison observed benchmark covariates. Default value 1 (latent variable strong benchmark covariate). ky numeric vector. Parameterizes many times stronger latent variables related (pot.) outcome comparison observed benchmark covariates. kd numeric vector. Parameterizes many times stronger latent variables related treatment comparison observed benchmark covariates. Default value kz. sensitivity.contour plot show adjusted lower limits confidence intervals ("lwr"), upper limit confidence intervals ("upr") t-values ("t-value")? parm contour plots estimate? Options iv instrumental variable estimates, fs first-stage estimates, rf reduced-form estimates. r2zw.x (optional) hypothetical partial R2 latent variables W instrument Z, given observed covariates X. r2y0w.zx (optional) hypothetical partial R2 latent variables W (pot.) outcome Y(0) given Z X. Default r2zw.x. bound_label label bounds provided manually r2zw.x r2y0w.zx. xlab label x axis. `NULL`, default label used. ylab label y axis. `NULL`, default label used.

title: Contour plots of omitted variable bias for IV — ovb_contour_plot
text: function called side effect producing contour plot. invisibly returns list grid values used contour plot.

title: Contour plots of omitted variable bias for IV — ovb_contour_plot
text: parameters include: alpha significance level. threshold critical threshold, default 0. lim limits axes. lim.x limits x axis. Default lim. lim.y limits y axis. Default lim. nlevels number levels contour plot. col.contour color contour lines. col.thr.line color threshold line. label.text benchmark label texts shown? Default TRUE. cex.label.text character size label text. Default .7. label.bump.x bump x coordinate label text. label.bump.y bump y coordinate label text. cex.lab magnification used x y labels relative current setting cex. cex.main magnification used main titles relative current setting cex. cex.axis magnification used axis annotation relative current setting cex. asp y/x aspect ratio. Default 1. parm = "fs" parm = "rf" function simply wrapper sensemakr function ovb_contour_plot.lm first-stage reduced-form lm models.

title: Contour plots of omitted variable bias for IV — ovb_contour_plot
text: Cinelli, C. Hazlett, C. (2020), "Making Sense Sensitivity: Extending Omitted Variable Bias." Journal Royal Statistical Society, Series B (Statistical Methodology). Cinelli, C. Hazlett, C. (2025), "Omitted Variable Bias Framework Sensitivity Analysis Instrumental Variables." Biometrika. doi:10.1093/biomet/asaf004

title: Contour plots of omitted variable bias for IV — ovb_contour_plot
code: data("card") y <- card$lwage d <- card$educ z <- card$nearc4 x <- model.matrix( ~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 + reg662 +                      reg663 + reg664 + reg665+ reg666 + reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                    data = card) card.fit <- iv_fit(y, d, z, x)  # contour plot of the lower CI limit ovb_contour_plot(card.fit, sensitivity.of = "lwr",                  benchmark_covariates = "black")

what: Minimal sensitivity reporting for IV estimates — ovb_minimal_reporting
title: Minimal sensitivity reporting for IV estimates — ovb_minimal_reporting
text: function produces LaTeX HTML code minimal sensitivity analysis table instrumental variable estimates, suggested Cinelli Hazlett (2025). objects class sensemakr (sensemakr package), dispatches sensemakr::ovb_minimal_reporting.

title: Minimal sensitivity reporting for IV estimates — ovb_minimal_reporting
code: ovb_minimal_reporting(   x,   digits = 3,   verbose = TRUE,   format = c("latex", "html", "pure_html"),   ... )

title: Minimal sensitivity reporting for IV estimates — ovb_minimal_reporting
text: x object class iv.sensemakr sensemakr. digits minimal number significant digits. verbose TRUE, function prints code cat. format code format print: "latex", "html" (requires mathjax), "pure_html". ... arguments passed table-building functions. Optional overrides include outcome_label treatment_label.

title: Minimal sensitivity reporting for IV estimates — ovb_minimal_reporting
text: function returns LaTeX HTML code invisibly character string also prints cat verbose = TRUE.

title: Minimal sensitivity reporting for IV estimates — ovb_minimal_reporting
text: Cinelli, C. Hazlett, C. (2025), "Omitted Variable Bias Framework Sensitivity Analysis Instrumental Variables." Biometrika. doi:10.1093/biomet/asaf004

title: Minimal sensitivity reporting for IV estimates — ovb_minimal_reporting
code:
# loads package library(iv.sensemakr) # loads dataset data("card") # prepares data y <- card$lwage d <- card$educ z <- card$nearc4 x <- model.matrix( ~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 + reg662 + reg663 + reg664 + reg665+ reg666 + reg667 + reg668 + smsa66, data = card) # fits IV model and runs sensitivity analysis card.fit <- iv_fit(y, d, z, x) card.sens <- sensemakr(card.fit, benchmark_covariates = c("black", "smsa")) # latex code ovb_minimal_reporting(card.sens) #> \begin{table}[!h] #> \centering #> \begin{tabular}{lrrrrrr} #> \multicolumn{7}{c}{Outcome: \textit{y}} \\ #> \hline \hline #> Treatment: & Est. & Lower CI & Upper CI & t-value & $XRV_{q = 1, \alpha = 0.05}$ & $RV_{q = 1, \alpha = 0.05}$ \\ #> \hline #> \textit{d} & 0.132 & 0.025 & 0.285 & 2.327 & 0.1\% & 0.7\% \\ #> \hline #> df = 2994 & & \multicolumn{5}{r}{ \small \textit{Bound (1x black)}: $R^2_{Z\sim W| {\bf X}}$ = 0.2\%, $R^2_{Y(0)\sim W| Z, {\bf X}}$ = 7.5\%} \\ #> \end{tabular} #> \end{table} # html code (pure html, no mathjax needed) ovb_minimal_reporting(card.sens, format = "pure_html") #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #>
Outcome: y
Treatment Est. Lower CI Upper CI t-value XRVq = 1, α = 0.05 RVq = 1, α = 0.05
d0.132 0.025 0.285 2.327 0.1% 0.7%
Note: df = 2994; Bound ( 1x black ): R2Z~W|X = 0.2%, R2Y(0)~W|Z,X = 7.5%

title: Sensitivity analysis print and summary methods for iv.sensemakr — summary.iv.sensemakr
code: data("card") y <- card$lwage d <- card$educ z <- card$nearc4 x <- model.matrix( ~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 + reg662 +                      reg663 + reg664 + reg665+ reg666 + reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                    data = card) card.fit <- iv_fit(y, d, z, x) card.sens <- sensemakr(card.fit, benchmark_covariates = "black") print(card.sens) #>  #> Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables #> (Anderson-Rubin Approach) #> ============================================================= #> IV Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.132 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.025, 0.285] #>  #> Sensitivity Statistics: #>   Extreme Robustness Value: 0.000523 #>   Robustness Value: 0.00667 #>  #> Bounds on Omitted Variable Bias: #>  Bound Label  R2zw.x R2y0w.zx Lower CI Upper CI Crit. Thr. #>     1x black 0.00221    0.075  -0.0212    0.402       2.59 #>  #> Note: H0 = 0, q >= 1, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ============================================================= #> See summary for first stage and reduced form. #>  summary(card.sens) #>  #> Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables #> (Anderson-Rubin Approach) #> ============================================================= #> IV Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.132 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.025, 0.285] #>  #> Sensitivity Statistics: #>   Extreme Robustness Value: 0.000523 #>   Robustness Value: 0.00667 #>  #> Bounds on Omitted Variable Bias: #>  Bound Label  R2zw.x r2y0w.zx Lower CI Upper CI Crit. Thr. #>     1x black 0.00221    0.075  -0.0212    0.402       2.59 #>  #> Note: H0 = 0, q >= 1, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ------------------------------------------------------------- #> FS Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.32 #>   Standard Error: 0.0879 #>   t-value: 3.64 #>   p-value: 0.000276 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.148, 0.492] #>  #> Sensitivity Statistics: #>   Extreme Robustness Value: 0.00313 #>   Robustness Value: 0.0302 #>  #> Bounds on Omitted Variable Bias: #>  Bound Label  R2zw.x R2dw.zx Lower CI Upper CI Crit. Thr. #>     1x black 0.00221  0.0334    0.109    0.531        2.4 #>  #> Note: H0 = 0, q = 1, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ------------------------------------------------------------- #> RF Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.0421 #>   Standard Error: 0.0181 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.007, 0.078] #>  #> Sensitivity Statistics: #>   Extreme Robustness Value: 0.000523 #>   Robustness Value: 0.00667 #>  #> Bounds on Omitted Variable Bias: #>  Bound Label  R2zw.x R2yw.zx Lower CI Upper CI Crit. Thr. #>     1x black 0.00221  0.0657 -0.00418   0.0883       2.56 #>  #> Note: H0 = 0, q = 1, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ============================================================= #>

what: Computes the (extreme) robustness value for IV — robustness_value
title: Computes the (extreme) robustness value for IV — robustness_value
text: Computes robustness values iv_fit objects, adapting robustness value definitions sensemakr instrumental variables described Cinelli Hazlett (2025). parm = "iv", returns robustness values IV estimate; parm = "fs" parm = "rf", dispatches sensemakr methods corresponding lm models.

title: Computes the (extreme) robustness value for IV — robustness_value
code: robustness_value(...)  extreme_robustness_value(...)  xrv(...)  rv(...)  # S3 method for class 'iv_fit' extreme_robustness_value(   model,   parm = "iv",   q = 1,   alpha = 0.05,   min = TRUE,   ... )  # S3 method for class 'iv_fit' robustness_value(model, parm = "iv", q = 1, alpha = 0.05, min = TRUE, ...)

title: Computes the (extreme) robustness value for IV — robustness_value
text: ... arguments passed methods. model iv_fit model parm parameter robustness value computed. Default iv, meaning robustness value IV estimate computed. options compute robustness value auxiliary estimates, first stage (fs) reduced form (rf). q percent change effect estimate deemed problematic. Default 1, means reduction (increase) 100% current effect estimate (bring estimate zero). greater zero. alpha significance level. min many cases, researchers interested biases large larger certain amount (instance, strength confounding bring positive estimate zero ). Setting min = TRUE (default) computes robustness value cases. Setting min = FALSE computes robustness value bias exactly q.

title: Computes the (extreme) robustness value for IV — robustness_value
text: numeric value (extreme) robustness value.

title: Computes the (extreme) robustness value for IV — robustness_value
text: Cinelli, C. Hazlett, C. (2025), "Omitted Variable Bias Framework Sensitivity Analysis Instrumental Variables." Biometrika. doi:10.1093/biomet/asaf004

title: Computes the (extreme) robustness value for IV — robustness_value
code: data("card") y <- card$lwage d <- card$educ z <- card$nearc4 x <- model.matrix( ~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 + reg662 +                      reg663 + reg664 + reg665+ reg666 + reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                    data = card) card.fit <- iv_fit(y, d, z, x)  # robustness value of the IV estimate rv(card.fit) #>      iv  #> 0.00667  #> Parameters: q >= 1, alpha = 0.05   # extreme robustness value xrv(card.fit) #>       iv  #> 0.000523  #> Parameters: q >= 1, alpha = 0.05   # robustness values for first-stage and reduced-form rv(card.fit, parm = "fs") #>     fs  #> 0.0302  #> Parameters: q = 1, alpha = 0.05, invert = FALSE  rv(card.fit, parm = "rf") #>      rf  #> 0.00667  #> Parameters: q = 1, alpha = 0.05, invert = FALSE

what: Sensitivity Analysis of Instrumental Variable Estimates — sensemakr
title: Sensitivity Analysis of Instrumental Variable Estimates — sensemakr
text: function performs sensitivity analysis instrumental variable estimates, discussed Cinelli Hazlett (2025). main input object class iv_fit. returns object class iv.sensemakr several pre-computed sensitivity statistics reporting. running sensemakr may directly use plot, print summary methods returned object.

title: Sensitivity Analysis of Instrumental Variable Estimates — sensemakr
code: sensemakr(...)  # S3 method for class 'iv_fit' sensemakr(   model,   benchmark_covariates = NULL,   kz = 1,   ky = kz,   kd = kz,   r2zw.x = NULL,   r2y0w.zx = r2zw.x,   bound_label = "Manual Bound",   q = 1,   alpha = 0.05,   min = TRUE,   ... )

title: Sensitivity Analysis of Instrumental Variable Estimates — sensemakr
text: ... arguments passed methods. model model created function iv_fit. benchmark_covariates character vector names covariates used bound plausible strength latent variables. kz numeric vector. Parameterizes many times stronger latent variables related instrument comparison observed benchmark covariates. Default value 1 (latent variable strong benchmark covariate). ky numeric vector. Parameterizes many times stronger latent variables related (pot.) outcome comparison observed benchmark covariates. kd numeric vector. Parameterizes many times stronger latent variables related treatment comparison observed benchmark covariates. Default value kz. r2zw.x (optional) hypothetical partial R2 latent variables W instrument Z, given observed covariates X. r2y0w.zx (optional) hypothetical partial R2 latent variables W (pot.) outcome Y(0) given Z X. Default r2zw.x. bound_label label bounds provided manually r2zw.x r2y0w.zx. q percent change effect estimate deemed problematic. Default 1, means reduction 100% current effect estimate (bring estimate zero). alpha significance level. min consider biases large larger certain amount? Default TRUE.

title: Sensitivity Analysis of Instrumental Variable Estimates — sensemakr
text: object class iv.sensemakr, containing: pars list general parameters used calling sensemakr. unadjusted list original, unadjusted results. sensitivity_stats list sensitivity statistics IV, First-Stage, Reduced-Form regressions. bounds list bounds strength latent variables "k times" strong benchmark covariates.

title: Sensitivity Analysis of Instrumental Variable Estimates — sensemakr
text: Cinelli, C. Hazlett, C. (2025), "Omitted Variable Bias Framework Sensitivity Analysis Instrumental Variables." Biometrika. doi:10.1093/biomet/asaf004

title: Sensitivity Analysis of Instrumental Variable Estimates — sensemakr
code: # loads package library(iv.sensemakr)  # loads dataset data("card")  # prepares data y <- card$lwage  # outcome d <- card$educ   # treatment z <- card$nearc4 # instrument x <- model.matrix( ~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 + reg662 +                      reg663 + reg664 + reg665+ reg666 + reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                    data = card) # covariates # fits IV model card.fit <- iv_fit(y,d,z,x)  # see results card.fit #>  #> Instrumental Variable Estimation #> (Anderson-Rubin Approach) #> ============================================= #> IV Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.132 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.025, 0.285] #> Note: H0 = 0, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ============================================= #> See summary for first stage and reduced form. #>   # runs sensitivity analysis card.sens <- sensemakr(card.fit, benchmark_covariates = c("black", "smsa"))  # see results card.sens #>  #> Sensitivity Analysis for Instrumental Variables #> (Anderson-Rubin Approach) #> ============================================================= #> IV Estimates: #>   Coef. Estimate: 0.132 #>   t-value: 2.33 #>   p-value: 0.02 #>   Conf. Interval: [0.025, 0.285] #>  #> Sensitivity Statistics: #>   Extreme Robustness Value: 0.000523 #>   Robustness Value: 0.00667 #>  #> Bounds on Omitted Variable Bias: #>  Bound Label  R2zw.x R2y0w.zx Lower CI Upper CI Crit. Thr. #>     1x black 0.00221   0.0750  -0.0212    0.402       2.59 #>      1x smsa 0.00639   0.0202  -0.0192    0.396       2.57 #>  #> Note: H0 = 0, q >= 1, alpha = 0.05, df = 2994. #> ============================================================= #> See summary for first stage and reduced form. #>   # sensitivity contour plot plot(card.sens, lim = 0.09)

what: Sensitivity statistics for instrumental variable estimates — sensitivity_stats
title: Sensitivity statistics for instrumental variable estimates — sensitivity_stats
text: Convenience function computes robustness values IV estimates well auxiliary first stage reduced form regressions.

title: Sensitivity statistics for instrumental variable estimates — sensitivity_stats
code: sensitivity_stats(...)  # S3 method for class 'iv_fit' sensitivity_stats(model, parm = "iv", q = 1, alpha = 0.05, min = TRUE, ...)  # S3 method for class 'iv.sensemakr' sensitivity_stats(model, parm = "iv", q = 1, alpha = 0.05, min = TRUE, ...)

title: Sensitivity statistics for instrumental variable estimates — sensitivity_stats
text: ... arguments passed methods. model model created function iv_fit. parm contour plots estimate? Options iv instrumental variable estimates, fs first-stage estimates, rf reduced-form estimates. q percent change effect estimate deemed problematic. Default 1, means reduction 100% current effect estimate (bring estimate zero). alpha significance level. min consider biases large larger certain amount? Default TRUE.

title: Sensitivity statistics for instrumental variable estimates — sensitivity_stats
text: data.frame columns estimate, confidence interval bounds (lower upper), t-value, extreme robustness value (xrv_qa), robustness value (rv_qa), parameters used (q, min, alpha, dof).

title: Sensitivity statistics for instrumental variable estimates — sensitivity_stats
code: data("card") y <- card$lwage d <- card$educ z <- card$nearc4 x <- model.matrix( ~ exper + expersq + black + south + smsa + reg661 + reg662 +                      reg663 + reg664 + reg665+ reg666 + reg667 + reg668 + smsa66,                    data = card) card.fit <- iv_fit(y, d, z, x)  # sensitivity statistics for the IV estimate sensitivity_stats(card.fit) #>     estimate        lwr       upr  t.value       xrv_qa       rv_qa q min alpha #> iv 0.1315038 0.02480484 0.2848236 2.327075 0.0005232443 0.006666407 1   1  0.05 #>     dof #> iv 2994  # sensitivity statistics for the first-stage sensitivity_stats(card.fit, parm = "fs") #>     estimate       lwr       upr t.value      xrv_qa      rv_qa q min alpha #> fs 0.3198989 0.1476194 0.4921785 3.64085 0.003129076 0.03023129 1   1  0.05 #>     dof #> fs 2994
